'''Edith North Johnson''' (January 2, 1903 – February 28, 1988)<ref name="Dead">[http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1980.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.com] - accessed September 2011</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[classic female blues]] singer, pianist and songwriter.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p188390|pure_url=yes}}|title=Edith North Johnson|author=Steve Leggett |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=September 26, 2011}}</ref> Her most noted tracks were "Honey Dripper Blues", "Can't Make Another Day" and "Eight Hour Woman".<ref name="Dead"/> She wrote another of her songs, "Nickel's Worth of Liver Blues".

==Biography==
Born '''Edith North''', in 1928 she married a local [[record producer]], Jesse Johnson.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Owsley">{{cite book
| first= Dennis
| last= Owsley
| year= 2006
| title= City of Gabriels: the history of jazz in St. Louis, 1895-1973
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Reedy Press
| location= St. Louis, Missouri
| isbn= 1-933370-04-1
| pages= 40/1}}</ref> She originally worked at her husband's Deluxe Music Store as a sales person.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Arnold
| last= Shaw
| year= 1986
| title= Black Popular Music in America
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Schirmer Books
| location= London, England
| isbn= 0-02-872310-4
| page= 105}}</ref> Although not a professional singer, between 1928 and 1929 Johnson recorded eighteen sides. She started on [[QRS Records]] in 1928, later switching to Paramount.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Bill
| last= Wyman
| year= 2001
| title= Bill Wyman's blues odyssey
| edition= 1st
| publisher= DK Publishing
| location= London
| isbn= 0-7894-8046-8
| page= 95}}</ref> Her output tally included those from a recording session in [[Grafton, Wisconsin]], for the [[Paramount Records|Paramount]] [[record label|label]] with [[Charley Patton]].  Oddly, it is now reckoned that Patton did not play on any of her recordings.<ref name="AMG"/>

During [[World War II]], Johnson managed a [[taxicab]] operation in St. Louis, as well as later running Johnson's Deluxe Cafė after her husband's death in 1946.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Owsley"/> By 1961, she had returned to recording when [[Samuel Charters]] tracked her down.  She was accompanied by Henry Brown on Charters' set entitled, ''The Blues in St. Louis''.  It was released by [[Folkways Records|Folkways]].<ref name="AMG"/>

Using pseudonyms such as Hattie North (on [[Vocalion Records|Vocalion]])<ref>{{cite book
| first= Allan
| last= Sutton
| year= 2005
| title= Pseudonyms on American records, 1892-1942
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= Mainspring Press
| location= Michigan
| isbn= 0-9671819-9-2
| page= 243}}</ref> and Maybelle Allen, Johnson also earlier waxed additional tracks for other small labels.<ref name="AMG"/> Under the Hattie North name, she recorded "Lovin' That Man Blues" with [[Count Basie]].<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=song|id=t1258904|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( "Lovin' That Man Blues" )))}}</ref>

Her recording of "Honey Dripper Blues" was the inspiration for the [[nickname]] used by [[Roosevelt Sykes]]. In her later life, Johnson spent time undertaking social work in her hometown.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Paul
| last= Oliver
| year= 1997
| title= Conversation with the blues
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= Cambridge University Press
| location= Cambridge, England
| isbn= 0-521-59181-3
| page= 184}}</ref>

Johnson died in St. Louis in February 1988, at the age of 85.<ref name="Dead"/>

Four of her songs appeared as part of the [[boxed set]], ''[[Screamin' and Hollerin' the Blues: The Worlds of Charley Patton]]'' (2001).<ref>{{cite web |first=Richie |last=Unterberger |title= ''Screamin' and Hollerin' the Blues'' > Review |url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r555300|pure_url=yes}} |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=September 26, 2011}}</ref>
